title: 106_hr4744
content: The Act is titled the "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purposes. The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" outlines findings that highlight the need for transparency in regulatory decisions and effective congressional oversight to ensure laws are implemented efficiently and fairly. The Act aims to increase accountability of Congress and agencies to the public they serve. The Act defines key terms such as "agency," "economically significant rule," and "independent evaluation" to ensure transparency and accountability in regulatory decisions. The Comptroller General evaluates data, methodology, and assumptions for rulemaking, explaining strengths and weaknesses that impact conclusions and implications. The Comptroller General evaluates data, methodology, and assumptions for rulemaking, explaining strengths and weaknesses that impact conclusions and implications. Additionally, a report on rules is required. When an agency publishes an economically significant rule, a committee member can request the Comptroller General to review it. The Comptroller General must submit a report within specific timeframes, providing an independent evaluation of the rule. The Comptroller General must conduct an independent evaluation of economically significant rules, assessing potential benefits, costs, and alternative approaches for cost-effectiveness or greater benefits. The Comptroller General evaluates economically significant rules, considering alternative cost-effective approaches and greater benefits. Procedures for prioritizing requests are developed in consultation with Senate and House leaders. The Comptroller General develops procedures for prioritizing requests for review of rules, giving highest priority to proposed rulemaking notices and interim final rulemaking. Agencies are required to cooperate with the Comptroller General. Authorization of appropriations for the General Accounting Office is set at $5,200,000 annually for fiscal years 2001 through 2003. The Act will take effect 180 days after enactment and will not apply to rules published three years after the effective date.
